section.p: For setting up the proxy, process the following steps:

section.name: 1. Install and configure a Linux operating system.
section.p: As a preconditon to run all kind of software needed on the proxy you have to setup a suitable Linux distribution as the operating system of the computer that works as your proxy. For detailed information please see the installation instructions provided by the vendor of your operating system.

section.name: 2. Install and configure BlueZ
section.p: BlueZ the official Bluetooth stack for Linux has to be installed as the next step of the proxy setup process. A detailed description how to do this can be found in the diploma thesis of Daniel Käppeli (Daniel Käppeli, DA, 2004 p.41 - p.47)

section.name: 3. Install and configure Impronto Developer Kit for Linux.
section.p: For a working Bluetooth communication some additional libraries have to be installed on you computer. A detailed description how to install them can also be found within the work done by Daniel Käppeli (Daniel Käppeli, DA, 2004 p.51 - p. 55)

section.name: 4. Install and start the Jadabs framework on your proxy.
section.p: The Jadabs framework as well as further bundles which are used for the communication with the SBB Midlet have to be installed on your system. Checkout (if possible) the latest stable release from CVS and place it together with some other bundles under ~/.maven/repository/${bundle.name}/jars

Create a folder where to checkout the 'jadabs-ws' project from CVS and checkout the complete project from CVS. Change to the folder where you checked out the project and go to "jadabs-ws/bundles/sbbproxy". There you will find 'start.sh', 'init.xargs' and 'log4j.properties' as well as some other project related files. To start the proxy run 'start.sh' and the Jadabs framework will come up on your proxy.
